awd_titl_txt: Understanding Interacting Binary Stars Identified in Astronomical Surveys
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is aimed at understanding how stars that are formed in binary pairs are distributed throughout our galaxy and how they evolve in time by interacting with each other. The team members will use telescope time available through their university to accomplish follow-up observations of variable objects that are identified in several current ongoing sky surveys. The results will reveal the number and nature of these systems that can be compared to theoretical evolution models to understand their evolution. This study also serves as preparation for the future Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (the NSF funded astronomy project recommended by the United States' 2010 Decadal Survey), by revealing the types of variables that will be found. The intellectual merit of the results include new understanding of how mass transfer between stars affects their evolution, how common these stars are at various locations in the galaxy, how magnetic fields enter into the evolution, and how variable the objects are at different evolution stages. The project has broad impact through building up and working with an international community of scientists that will know how to maximize results from the future Synoptic Telescope, including undergraduate students in STEM fields as well as graduate and postdoctoral students in astronomy.

The investigators will use Apache Point Observatory to obtain spectra, radial velocities, and high time-resolution light curves of cataclysmic variables from ongoing sky surveys (Sloan, Catalina, Kepler, and Palomar) in order to further the understanding of the evolution of  interacting close binary stars. The results will determine the galactic  distribution, test population models, and the purity of the instability strip for accreting white dwarfs, parameterize the population containing magnetic  white dwarfs, as well as reveal the number and nature of variables that will be present in the future Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST). The new results include number densities out of the galactic plane, physical parameters of the variables at the shortest orbital periods, angular momentum losses, heating and cooling resulting from accretion changes, as well as the numbers containing magnetic white dwarfs. A broader impact of these results is the buildup of an international community of astronomers, including undergraduate STEM students, graduate students and postdocs that will be able to exploit the LSST by identifying and following up close binaries of interest.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Interacting binary systems provide a natural laboratory for the studyof how mass transfer from one star to another affects the long term evolution of the stars. As binary systems are very common in our Galaxy,the numbers and orbital periods of these systems, especially as a function of their position in our Galaxy, provides insight into how stellar populations change as a galaxy evolves. Cataclysmic variables (CVs)are unique interacting binaries with a cool star transferring mass to a white dwarf. Their eruptive behavior enable themto be easily identified in several ongoing large-scale sky surveys, and the close proximity of the two stars means that the orbital periods are short (hours) and can be easily determined during short (sometimes single-night) observations.

This project involved identifying and studying in detail (through followup spectroscopy and photometry) cataclysmic variables from the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF), the Sloan Digital Sky Survey, the All-Sky Automated Survey for Supernovae (ASASSN), and the Kepler K2 and TESS missions. The published ZTF results revealed hundreds of new candidate CVs and showed  their  increased numbers at low galactic latitudes. Studies of individual systems using the weeks-months continuous cadence of K2 and TESS revealed the timescales for changes in mass transfer and accretion events, as well as a better understanding of the accretion scenarios in systems with highly magnetic white dwarfs. Following a couple systems that contained pulsating white dwarfs with high-speed photometry throughout this project enabled a better grasp of how the accretion affects the temperature of the white dwarf and its interior, aspects that have implications for evolutionary scenarios leading to supernovae, 

A web site for discoveries from current sky surveys was publicly launched.The sky-survey and followup data were analyzed with undergrads, grad students, postdocs and colleagues throughout the world, cementing a community that will work together with the larger sky survey (LSST) currently under construction.


Last Modified: 09/17/2021
Modified by: Paula Szkody
